chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure every resident has access to a core package of essential healthcare—especially primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency care—so illness never leads to medical bankruptcy. Rather than running every part of the system, it should set enforceable coverage and quality standards, use transparent purchasing/price negotiation to curb costs, and offer income-based support while allowing regulated private plans and providers to compete on service and outcomes. Simple, portable enrollment and clear public reporting of prices and results can protect choice, reduce bureaucracy, and keep the system accountable to taxpayers and patients.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a dependable baseline of affordable, high-quality healthcare—especially preventive, mental health, emergency, and catastrophic coverage—so no one is denied essential care or driven into medical bankruptcy. It should set clear standards, ensure transparent pricing and quality reporting, and use targeted subsidies plus streamlined administration to cut waste and protect taxpayers. Within that public floor, regulated private and local provider partnerships can expand options and spur innovation, with accountability and value-based incentives to keep costs sustainable and outcomes improving.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should guarantee every resident access to a basic package of essential care—primary, preventive, mental health, and emergency services—with strong protection from catastrophic medical bills. To respect choice and encourage innovation, people who want more coverage can use regulated private plans, while government sets clear quality standards, reduces paperwork, and requires price and outcome transparency. Costs should be kept in check through fair negotiations, anti-fraud enforcement, and targeted subsidies based on need, with flexibility for states and local providers to deliver care efficiently.
